question: Where is the Sun located, given that it is at the center of our solar system and our solar system lies at the edge of the Milky Way galaxy?

content.source_1: The Sun resides in the Milky Way’s disk about 26,000–28,000 light-years from the Galactic Center, within the Orion Arm (also called the Orion Spur).
content.source_2: The Orion Arm is a minor spiral feature positioned between the larger Sagittarius and Perseus arms of the Milky Way.
content.source_3: Astronomers locate the Milky Way’s center on the sky in the constellation Sagittarius, near the compact radio source Sagittarius A*.
content.source_4: Because Earth orbits the Sun, the Sun’s apparent position moves through the zodiac and is seen in front of the constellation Sagittarius for several weeks each year around December–January.
content.source_5: The ecliptic—the Sun’s apparent annual path across the sky—passes through the constellation Sagittarius.
content.source_6: The densest, brightest stretch of the Milky Way band visible from Earth lies toward the Sagittarius region of the sky.

answer: Our Sun is the center of a solar system in the Milky Way galaxy.
